text: foreign
hi everyone welcome to the YouTube
channel here the internet's busiest
music nerd and it's time for a review of
this new Tim Hecker album
no highs this is a brand new LP from
ambient and experimental music composer
sound Alchemist Mr Tim Hecker this is
said to be his 11th full-length LP and
arrives at what is uh potentially the
start of a new chapter in his career
years and years and years ago in the
2000s Tim Hecker was once building one
of the most consistent and respectable
catalogs in ambient music to come out of
Canada haunting and droney high water
marks like Harmony and UltraViolet and
radio and more still hold up to this day
the 2010s in comparison were a much more
volatile time for Tim's catalog there
were a few drablos he also did some
collaborating some soundtrack work but
there were some incredible highs during
this point in his career too like the
dismally apocalyptic piano pieces
littered all over Rave death 1972 or my
personal favorite virgins which may be
Tim's most unsettling and textually
gratifying project to date which is
actually 10 years old this year and was
my album of the year when it dropped
then there's where we last heard Tim
dropping two sister records less than a
year apart where a bulk of the material
on these projects was inspired by the
instrumentation and musical modes of
Japanese classical music not my favorite
records in his catalog but certainly a
surprise and had me wondering where he
would take things next however no highs
feels more like familiar than foreign
territory for Tim while it's not as
thick or as droney as some of his most
beloved material the strange Eerie and
slightly Melancholy Vibes are back in a
big way in a series of instrumental
pieces that in their best moments feel
like a vision of end times you could
catch some feel bad vibes just based off
the song titles on this thing alone the
synths are also back in a big way on
this project with seemingly no real
um angle in sight which is interesting
because a lot of Tim's material
throughout the 2010s did a kind of hinge
on an idea or a concept there there was
typically a kicker but really if there's
a narrative to this record it's Tim
going back to doing what he does best
again the synths are layered and
colorful and thick the atmosphere
they're soaked in is immersive and
moments from this thing that feature a
lot of repeating cycles and melodic
sequences are especially mesmerizing
which is actually the first thing Tim
hits us with on the opening monotony
this over time gets drowned out in all
matter of swelling wailing droning tones
and the sound of what's going on here
gives me the sensation of swimming in a
freezing cold ocean or falling through
an overcast sky or endlessly walking
through an abandoned city either way I
feel like I'm enveloped in something
much larger than myself and feeling very
alone in this space in many ways this
track is the perfect Hecker piece
because there is quite a bit of
progression and I'll say change over the
course of its run time to keep things
engaging but by that same token and the
progression isn't really the draw it's
truly the fact that you can just feel
lost in this piece forever now there's
also a part two on this track that pops
up later in the tracklist featuring none
other than saxophone player
extraordinaire Colin Stetson which is
funny because I thought some of the
howling tones on the intro uh could have
been him or sounded somewhat like
something he would do there are some
other random moments on the lp where
there's clearly like some saxophones and
read instruments subtly popping in here
and there but yeah the roll Colin plays
on the second part of monotony is far
from just like you know a background
layer just a bit of subtle accompaniment
as he's known to do he just kind of
Cycles through these fluttering modal
runs that just play continuously because
you know he's got like that infinite
breathing technique going and I suppose
his inclusion on the record is cool for
the moment it lasts I wish there was a
bit more interplay between Tim synthwork
and Collins playing for the duration
that it is like in the Limelight or
maybe just that this passage here was
included on the original song in some
way but other riveting pieces on this
record also include the eight minute
anxiety whose opening synth passages
persistently pulsate like a piece of
Machinery in a tech or medical lab the
initial moments in this song sound like
white walls and blinding fluorescent
light the track grows more and more
hypnotic as it repeats but slowly over
time it's like the world this synth
sequence exists in grows colder and the
frequency that it's coming to us through
is beginning to fade and the finish of
the whole thing is quite cinematic
showing these tattered and blown out
chords just smothering that original sin
sequence we've been hearing up until
this point and there's a similar formula
going on with the track Lotus light
where again you've got that clear synth
pulse right from the start but this
track is one of the moments on the lp
where it's the most difficult to
maintain sight of this synth part
because it seemingly fall falls into a
haze of noise and drones pretty quickly
which gives me this sensation uh
instantly of just feeling lost drowning
in waves of drones and Haze now other
cuts on the lp like in your mind and
total garbage may not be as lengthy as
these pieces but they're still
gratifying in their own right especially
the latter of the two which features
some tragic chords that skip like
they're playing off a broken record
these are then orbited by swelling beds
of weepy strings the only downside
really is that it doesn't last longer
but if there's one thing about Tim
Hecker he can create a really evocative
ambient piece within a fraction of the
time it takes many other artists in the
field however I wouldn't say a lot of
the shorter cuts on this thing are
consistently highlights they often come
across like aimless palette cleansers
meant to kind of kill time until we get
to a more robust piece in the track list
and I appreciate that a lot of these
Cuts segue into each other very fluidly
but often the instrumental palettes and
The Melodies that we switch from from
track to track uh feel pretty distinct
and have a hard contrast or a very
striking a little jarring so as a result
of that when I do hear a new idea or a
new sound I would hope to hear that
either develop to a point where I'm
gratified with the progression or for it
to reach a place where I feel at least a
little bit lost in it as opposed to just
I don't know kind of held over until
something more immersive occurs but yeah
this vast difference in depth and length
and tone from song to song on the record
does leave the flow of this record a
little choppy as far as the final
moments on this LP go we have sense
suppression which is a shorter cut that
pretty much seems like it's thrown in
here to set things up for the finisher
Living Spa water which is one of the
longer Cuts here but interesting that it
doesn't really seem to follow the
formula of any of the other uh bigger
moments on this LP there's no repetitive
synth passage or guiding pulse to kick
things off at the start but I suppose it
really does live up to its name because
the sonics Tim does hit us with I do
feel like an embodiment of water
additionally I would say The Vibes on
this track are surprisingly relaxing
which is kind of odd for Tim to embrace
in this era of his career especially on
a record here that has been so
persistently dark up until this point
but yeah this track kind of comes across
disappointingly like a really mild Cincy
New Age piece because while I do like
the midpoint and it's ghostly swells of
synths I just feel like the ascending
and descending tones again toward the
very end leave things feeling cold and
kind of aimless there's not really a
whole lot of tension or moodiness or
anything uh to comment on at this point
in the piece but yeah overall I would
say this is a pretty good record from
Tim a lot of highlights on it but it
doesn't really stick The Landing the
lengthiest pieces here are really the
draw to the album for me and it is cool
to hear Tim return to form a little bit
and release some kind of dark and melon
Kali ambient pieces that are vast that
are deep and above all are entrancing
I'm feeling a light seven on this one
transition have you given this album a
listen did you love it did you hate it
but would you rate it you're the best
you're the best what should I review
next hit the like if you like Please
Subscribe and please don't cry hit the
Bell as well over here next to my head
is another video you can check out hit
that up with a link to subscribe to the
channel Anthony fantana Tim Hecker the
forever
